questions.clue: This Italian city is famous for its canals and the annual Venice Biennale, a major contemporary art exhibition.
Known for his detailed frescoes in the Sistine Chapel, this artist also sculpted the famous Statue of David.
The San Antonio Spurs share their black-and-white color scheme with this Italian art style characterized by its stark contrast and dramatic effects.
This architect designed the dome of the Florence Cathedral, a masterpiece of Renaissance architecture completed in 1436.
Lorenzo Ghiberti's famous bronze doors, dubbed the 'Gates of Paradise', are located at this Florentine landmark.

categories.name: NBA Finals: San Antonio Spurs Edition

questions.clue: This player, known for his defensive prowess and leadership, won Finals MVP in 1999, 2003, and 2005 with the San Antonio Spurs.
In 2014, this Italian player provided key minutes off the bench for the Spurs in their NBA Finals victory over the Miami Heat.
The San Antonio Spurs won their very first NBA Championship in this year, defeating the New York Knicks.
This French point guard was named NBA Finals MVP in 2007, becoming the first European to win the award.
In the 2013 NBA Finals, the Spurs lost to the Miami Heat in a seven-game series; this player hit a crucial three-pointer for Miami in Game 6.
This Italian dessert, often flavored with coffee, means 'pick me up' in Italian.
A staple in German bakeries, this cake is known for its layers of chocolate sponge, whipped cream, and cherries.
Known for its green color, this Swedish cake is covered with marzipan and often serves as a birthday treat.
Named after a town in Austria, this chocolate cake features a layer of apricot jam and a chocolate glaze.
This traditional Mexican cake, meaning 'three milks', is known for its moist texture achieved by soaking it in three types of milk.
This Italian explorer is credited with discovering the Americas in 1492, though he never set foot on the mainland.
Ferdinand Magellan, who led the first expedition to circumnavigate the globe, named this ocean for its peacefulness.
This Portuguese explorer was the first European to reach India by sea, linking Europe and Asia via the Cape of Good Hope.
Italian explorer John Cabot, sailing under the English flag, is credited with discovering parts of North America in 1497, including what is now this Canadian province.
Famous for his exploration of the Colorado River and the Grand Canyon, this one-armed explorer also has a San Antonio Spurs player named after him.
For 200 points: 'It was the best of times, it was the worst of times...' begins this Charles Dickens novel set in part in London and Paris.
For 400 points: 'Call me Ishmael.' opens this Herman Melville novel about a great white whale.
For 600 points: This novel starts with 'In my younger and more vulnerable years my father gave me some advice that I've been turning over in my mind ever since.' and is set in the Jazz Age.
For 800 points: 'All happy families are alike; each unhappy family is unhappy in its own way.' is the opening line of this Russian classic by Leo Tolstoy.
For 1000 points: This novel begins with 'In a hole in the ground there lived a hobbit.' and was written by J.R.R. Tolkien.

final.clue: This Italian dessert, which means 'pick me up', is made with layers of coffee-soaked ladyfingers and mascarpone cheese, and shares its name with a term used in basketball for a quick comeback or boost.
